--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Mitchell Timin wrote:
> 
> >Could someone explain the supposed advantages of
> XML? 
> >I can't see the benefit; only that its hard to
> read,
> >and occupies a lot more bytes.
> >
> >  
> >
> Hi Mitchell, as I see it there are several benefits
> to using XML:
> 
> 1) Provided you use an XML Document Object Model
> (DOM) framework it cuts 
> down on the amount of I/O code you have to write
> because the XML 
> processor loads the document into an internal
> representation that can 
> then be programatically queried and modified.
> 
> 2) For trivial flat data formats the benefits are
> minimal, but  for 
> hierarchical data formats and formats that are
> likely to grow your I/O 
> code won't be broken by the addition of new XML tags
> to a document. Your 
> code queries the DOM for XML tags that it knows
> about. Any newer tags or 
> tags you'r not interested in are simply ignored.
> 
> 3) Because unknown tags can be ignored this makes
> XML ideal for defining 
> data interchange standards. XML from external
> sources (e.g. a different 
> NEAT implememntation) can be checked against a
> definition file. 
> Historically this was done with a Data Type
> Definition (DTD) file, the 
> more recent approach is to use XML Schema Definition
> (XSD) files. XSD 
> can allow for 'open-ended' areas in the XML that
> allow for non-standard 
> XML to be legal, e.g. tags that are specific to a
> particular NEAT 
> implemenation that no-one else cares about.  
> 
> 4) Easy and standardised manipulation. The XML
> Stylesheet Language 
> Transformation (XSLT)   is itself an XML dialect
> that has been adopted 
> by the W3C. Transformations can be written to
> transform XML into a new 
> format. A nice example as mentioned on this group
> would be converting 
> NEAT network XML into SVG (Another XML dialect for
> defining graphics) 
> that can then be rendered with an SVG viewer.
> 
> 5) Readability of the data. OK I admit that this is
> subjective :)
> 
> XML is everywhere these days. E.g the HTML
> 'language' which historically 
> was a bit of an untamed beast has been standardised
> as an XML dialect - 
> XHTML. This gratefully simplifies web development
> since XHTML pages can 
> now be manipulated and built with standard and
> already existing XML 
> processors. The old windows INI files have mostly
> been replaced with 
> XML, look at any config file in Windows for an
> example. My own day job 
> revolves around building XML manipulation tools and
> defining XML 
> dialects that are used to convey data between
> companies, 
> insurance/mortgage applications, that sort of thing.
> 
> XML isn't suited for everything but it's always
> worth considering and 
> I'd recommend you cast an eye over the wealth of
> info on the web before 
> dismissing it :)

Thanks for the reply; cleary you put some effort into
it.  I am still not able to see its value for
scientific work.  It seems to me to be a part of
business and web programming, where perhaps it is
useful.  For scientific work I think it will mainly be
a source of delay and failed projects.  Don't forget
that learning about the various software systems you
mentioned requires time.  

=====
Mitchell Timin
